title: Alfonso V of Aragon Attends Fernando's Baptism Personally

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The autumn sun hung low over Toledo as the royal household prepared for the baptism of Prince Fernando. Servants bustled through the Alcázar's corridors, hanging fresh tapestries and polishing silver that would grace the feast tables. Archbishop Alonso de Toledo had spent days rehearsing the ceremony with his deacons, determined that this baptism—the christening of Castile's heir—would be spoken of for generations. But it was the arrival on October 10th that set the court buzzing. King Alfonso V of Aragon sailed into Santander with a fleet of six galleys, having left his Naples operations in the capable hands of his brother Pedro and his condottieri captains. He traveled overland with a retinue of forty—modest by royal standards, but including several figures of note: Don Bernat de Centelles (freshly returned from Rome), the Bishop of Valencia, and a train of mules bearing gifts that required their own escort.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: He's come himself, Your Majesty. Not the Queen, not a proxy. Alfonso himself, with nearly a week to spare before the baptism.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The reunion took place in the Alcázar's great hall, stripped of its mourning black but not yet fully restored to celebration. Alfonso entered with the confident stride of a man who had made a decision and was satisfied with it. At thirty-seven, he looked weathered by Mediterranean campaigns—sun-darkened skin, new lines around his eyes—but his embrace of Juan was genuine and warm.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Cuñado, I could not let another man stand where I should stand. Not for this.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The Naples situation—

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: René probes, the Genoese scheme, the Pope dithers despite his fine words. It will all still be there when I return. But my godson will only be baptized once. Besides, I have news that required speaking face to face, not trusting to letters and messengers.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: After the ceremony. Tonight is for family, not strategy. And this must be the princess who has inherited her mother's spirit, if reports are true.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: That evening, the Alcázar hosted a private dinner—just the immediate royal household and Alfonso's closest companions. The mood was subdued compared to what a baptismal celebration might normally be; Isabel's absence hung over everything, her empty chair at the table a silent reminder of what had been lost scarcely two months before. But Alfonso proved himself a sensitive guest. He spoke of Isabel warmly, sharing a memory from their childhood in the Castilian court—how she had once beaten him at chess when she was only nine, and he a proud teenager of fifteen.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: She looked at me afterward, and said, 'You let me win.' I told her I hadn't. She said, 'Then you should have. Now everyone saw you lose to a little girl.' Sharp as a Toledo blade, even then. Castile was lucky to have her, however briefly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Later, after Catalina had been taken to bed and the servants had withdrawn, Alfonso leaned forward with the expression of a man shifting from courtesy to business.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The news I mentioned. Two matters, both significant. First—Pope Eugenius has written to René of Anjou directly, informing him that the Holy See no longer recognizes his claim to Naples. The letter cites the strategic necessity of Aragonese naval power for the Constantinople expedition. René is reportedly furious. His French allies are making noise about the Pope overstepping. But it stands. Your advocacy in Rome bore fruit.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: This arrived in Palermo three weeks ago. From Emperor John VIII Palaiologos himself. He's heard about Castile's commitment to Constantinople. He's heard about the Military Order knights, the naval construction, the crusading treasury you've built. And he has a proposal.

roll.outcome: Alfonso attends with full honors and extended stay. Views this as investment in the alliance. Arrives early, participates fully, uses occasion for substantial diplomatic discussions about Constantinople expedition, Naples coordination, and future cooperation. His presence signals serious Iberian partnership.

encounters.recap: King Alfonso V of Aragon travels personally from Sicily to Toledo to serve as godfather to Prince Fernando's baptism, demonstrating his commitment to the Castilian alliance. He brings news that Pope Eugenius has officially withdrawn recognition of René of Anjou's claim to Naples and delivers a letter from Byzantine Emperor John VIII Palaiologos with a proposal regarding Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v_of_aragon
exchanges.text: And the second matter?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso reached into his doublet and withdrew a folded letter, sealed with Byzantine purple wax.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v_of_aragon
exchanges.text: This arrived in Palermo three weeks ago. From Emperor John VIII Palaiologos himself. He's heard about Castile's commitment to Constantinople. He's heard about the Military Order knights, the naval construction, the crusading treasury you've built. And he has a proposal.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan broke the seal and began to read. The letter from Constantinople bore the Emperor's desperate plea—the city was dying. Forty thousand people where once a million lived. Empty districts, crumbling walls, and decades of poverty. The three hundred Castilian knights had lifted spirits but could not save an empire. The Emperor asked for true alliance, sustained commitment, and for Juan himself to come to Constantinople.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan set the letter down slowly. The candles flickered in the evening breeze from the open window.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Sotomayor's report is attached. Twelve pages. The Emperor does not exaggerate.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Forty thousand people. Toledo has more than that.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v_of_aragon
exchanges.text: The walls can hold. Sotomayor is clear on that. The Theodosian fortifications are the greatest in the world—even undermanned, even with sections in poor repair. What they cannot do is hold forever without relief.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, this is... this is not a military problem. A thousand knights, ten thousand knights—they cannot rebuild a dying city. This is asking Castile to prop up an empire.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v_of_aragon
exchanges.text: I have been thinking about this since the letter arrived. About what Castile could actually do that would matter. Not just knights—anyone can send knights. Something that changes the calculation.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v_of_aragon
exchanges.text: Naval power. The Turk has armies, but his fleet is nothing compared to what it could be. Constantinople's sea walls are its strongest defense—the Theodosian walls face only the landward approach. If Castile's new fleet, combined with Aragonese galleys and Venetian support, controlled the approaches to the Bosphorus...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Interesting. I will visit soon. And take stock for ourselves. How is the campaign going in Naples? Anything I can do to help? The sooner this conflict is won and won strongly by you, the better.

roll.outcome: Dire: Slow Decay. No active siege, but the city is dying slowly. Population has fallen below 50,000. Entire districts stand empty. The walls show decades of deferred maintenance. Ottoman control of surrounding territory means food prices are extortionate.

encounters.recap: Emperor John VIII Palaiologos sends a desperate letter through Alfonso requesting true alliance with Castile. Constantinople is dying slowly—only 40,000 people remain, walls are crumbling, and the empire survives on Ottoman sufferance. Alfonso proposes naval power as the key to changing the strategic balance. Juan commits to visiting Constantinople personally to assess the situation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso's expression shifted—a flicker of genuine gratitude beneath the diplomatic mask.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: The campaign. Better than it was. Worse than I'd hoped.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Your advocacy in Rome changed everything. When Eugenius declared for my claim over René's, half the Neapolitan nobility suddenly remembered they'd always supported Aragon. Remarkable how papal favor clarifies men's loyalties.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: René of Anjou is furious, as I said. He's writing to every court in Europe claiming the Pope overstepped his authority. The French are making noise about supporting him, but Charles VII has his own problems—the English still hold half his kingdom, and he's more concerned with that than with his cousin's Italian ambitions.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So René lacks the strength to contest you directly?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: For now. He has partisans in Naples itself—the Angevin faction isn't dead, just cowed. And Genoa... Genoa remains the problem. They see Aragonese control of Naples as a threat to their Mediterranean trade. Filippo Maria Visconti in Milan plays both sides, promising support to whoever seems stronger that week.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: What do you need, Your Majesty? Specifically?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Three things would end this quickly. Gold. Always gold. Condottieri don't fight for promises, and I'm maintaining an army in Sicily while preparing the invasion fleet. Forty thousand florins would let me hire Francesco Sforza away from whoever's currently paying him. Sforza alone is worth five thousand men.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Ships. Not for transport—I have enough galleys for that. Combat vessels to counter Genoa if they intervene. Your new fleet, Juan... four armed carracks with modern cannon would make the Genoese think twice about challenging me at sea.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Diplomatic pressure. If Castile made clear to Genoa and Milan that Aragonese success in Naples serves Iberian interests—that interference would be remembered—it might give Visconti pause. He's a schemer, not a warrior. He won't risk a wider war if he thinks the costs outweigh the gains.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: With those three things? I take Naples by spring. Without them? Perhaps a year. Perhaps two. Perhaps René finds enough French gold to make a real fight of it.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: You spoke of winning strongly. Strong victory requires speed. The longer this drags on, the more opportunities my enemies have to coordinate against me. And the longer I'm tied down in Italy...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The longer Constantinople waits.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Yes. I read the Emperor's letter before I brought it to you. Forty thousand people in a city built for a million. I've seen dying cities, Juan. I watched Naples tear itself apart during Joanna's madness. Constantinople is worse—it's not even fighting anymore. It's just... fading.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: If you want me at your side when you sail to the Bosphorus, help me finish Naples first. Then Aragon's fleet joins Castile's. Then we go east together, as we discussed at the Te Deum. Three kingdoms united.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Done. Alvaro, prepare the treasury to dispense these funds and for a diplomatic message towards Genoa and Milan. The ships are barely built and will be used by me to travel to Constantinople. But I can anchor them in ports on full display so Genoa knows that they are in operation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Alfonso rose from his chair and clasped Juan's hand firmly—not the formal gesture of kings, but the grip of a brother-in-law who had just received more than he'd dared ask for.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Cuñado, you do not haggle. You do not hesitate. I will not forget this.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro was already making notes, his quill scratching against parchment.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Forty thousand florins to be drawn from the treasury. I'll have the letters of credit prepared for Your Majesty's signature tomorrow. The funds can travel with King Alfonso when he departs, or be sent directly to his bankers in Barcelona—whichever is more secure.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v
exchanges.text: Barcelona. Genoese pirates have been known to intercept shipments in the Tyrrhenian Sea. Better the gold travels overland through Aragon.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: And the diplomatic messages. To Genoa—what tone does Your Majesty wish to strike?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Firm but not threatening. Make clear that Castile views the resolution of the Naples question as vital to Iberian interests. That we have committed substantial resources to King Alfonso's success. That we would view any interference in this matter as an unfriendly act toward the Crown of Castile.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: And Milan?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Similar, but... softer. Visconti is a schemer, as Alfonso says. Give him room to scheme his way toward neutrality. Remind him that Castile has no quarrel with Milan, that we respect his position in Lombardy, that we hope he will recognize the wisdom of allowing the Naples question to resolve itself without Milanese entanglement.

encounters.recap: Juan commits full support to Alfonso's Naples campaign, providing 40,000 florins, naval display of force at Valencia, and diplomatic pressure on Genoa and Milan. Alfonso explains his strategic needs and timeline, with both kings agreeing to coordinate the Naples campaign completion with Juan's planned Constantinople expedition in spring 1434.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The four Portuguese ladies arrived in Juan's private study the following morning, summoned from their quarters in the Alcázar's east wing. They entered together, as they had done everything together since arriving in Castile three years ago—a small island of Portuguese voices in a Castilian sea. Doña Beatriz de Meneses entered first, the eldest at thirty-two, her face showing the strain of the past months. She had been Isabel's chief lady-in-waiting, her confidante, the one who had held Isabel's hand during Fernando's birth and closed her eyes afterward. Behind her came the others: Doña Inês de Castro, twenty-six, quiet and observant; Doña Leonor de Almeida, twenty-four, who had been closest to Isabel in age and temperament; and Doña Filipa de Vilhena, the youngest at twenty, who still looked lost without the queen she had served since childhood. All four wore black. All four curtsied deeply. Álvaro withdrew to give the king privacy, closing the door softly behind him.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_meneses
exchanges.text: Your Majesty honors us with this summons. We are... we are managing, Your Majesty. As one manages. The truth is, Your Majesty, we have been uncertain of our position since... since the Queen's passing. Queen Leonor asked me to remain for the children—and I will, for as long as Your Majesty permits. Catalina knows my face. She comes to me when she is frightened. And Fernando... Fernando will need to know who his mother was. I can tell him. I knew her since she was twelve years old.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_almeida
exchanges.text: I have written to my father in Lisbon. He has offered to arrange a marriage for me, if... if Your Majesty no longer requires my service. I do not wish to leave. But I do not know if there is a place for us here anymore. Without the Queen...

exchanges.speaker: ines_de_castro
exchanges.text: We are Portuguese ladies in a Castilian court, Your Majesty. We served your Queen. But you will marry again—you must, we understand this—and your new Queen will bring her own ladies. Her own language. Her own ways.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Filipa, the youngest, said nothing. Her eyes were red-rimmed. She had been weeping again—she had wept every day since August.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_meneses
exchanges.text: We do not ask for charity, Your Majesty. We ask only to know your will. Should we return to Portugal? Should we remain until your remarriage and then withdraw? Should we— Queen Leonor suggested that some of us might remain permanently, to ensure Catalina and Fernando know their Portuguese heritage. But we did not know if this was... if Your Majesty would wish...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Dona Beatriz, you have my gratitude and I would welcome you should you want to stay. I know Catalina knows and trusts you and that is worth a lot to me. I like to have someone Portugese near my children. I do not hold you here should you not wish to be here. If you want to return to Portugal, do so with my blessing and thanks. You have done your duty honourably. You will always be welcome at my court. Think about it. You can stay here, even marry should you wish it.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_meneses
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious beyond measure. I will stay. Not from duty—duty ended when my Queen drew her last breath. I stay because I loved her, and because her children deserve to know that love did not die with her. As for marriage... I am thirty-two, Your Majesty. I was betrothed once, in Portugal, but he died of fever before the wedding. I had made my peace with serving Isabel for the rest of my days. God had other plans. But I am not opposed to the idea, should... should such an opportunity arise. I had simply stopped thinking of it as possible.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_almeida
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, if I may... my father's offer of a marriage in Portugal is not urgent. He wrote out of concern for my future, not because a match is already arranged. If there is a place for me here—truly a place, not merely charity—I would rather stay. Isabel was... Isabel was my friend. Not just my queen. The thought of returning to Lisbon, where no one knew her as I did, where I cannot visit her tomb or speak her name to people who remember her smile... I ask only that Your Majesty be honest with us. If your new Queen will not want Portuguese ladies in her household, tell us now. We would rather know than hope falsely.

exchanges.speaker: filipa_de_vilhena
exchanges.text: I don't know what to do, Your Majesty. I came to Castile when I was seventeen. I have no marriage prospects in Portugal—my family is minor nobility, we have little dowry to offer. Isabel said she would find me a good Castilian husband someday. She said she would take care of me. And now she's gone and I don't know where I belong anymore.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Over the following days, Juan met with each lady separately in his study, Álvaro present as witness and keeper of accounts.

encounters.recap: Juan meets with Isabel's four Portuguese ladies-in-waiting to discuss their uncertain future. He offers them the choice to return to Portugal or remain at court, with Beatriz accepting to stay and care for the children. Juan privately grants each lady 40 florins toward their dowries to secure their futures.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Over the following days, Juan met with each lady separately in his study, Álvaro present as witness and keeper of accounts.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Leonor de Almeida received the news with wide eyes. Forty florins was more than her family could have scraped together for her dowry in Portugal—enough to make her attractive to minor Castilian nobility, perhaps even a wealthy merchant family seeking to elevate their standing.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_almeida
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I... This is too generous. I served my Queen, nothing more. I did my duty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro explained the arrangement in his measured tone: the funds would be held in the royal treasury, recorded under her name, released upon her marriage or upon her departure for Portugal should she choose that path. Safe from theft, safe from misfortune, hers by right whenever she claimed them.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_almeida
exchanges.text: I will stay, Your Majesty. And I will find a good Castilian husband and raise Castilian children who will know that their mother served the greatest queen this kingdom ever had.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Inês de Castro, the quiet one, listened to the offer in silence. When Álvaro finished explaining, she simply stared at the floor for a long moment.

exchanges.speaker: ines_de_castro
exchanges.text: My father lost most of our lands to debt. I was sent to serve Isabel because it was the only future my family could afford to give me. I expected to serve until I was too old to be useful, and then... I did not expect anything.

exchanges.speaker: ines_de_castro
exchanges.text: Forty florins is more than my family's remaining estate is worth, Your Majesty. You have given me a future I did not believe I would have. I will stay. And I will pray for Your Majesty's happiness every day of my life.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Filipa de Vilhena, the youngest, wept through the entire meeting. Not from sorrow this time—from overwhelming emotion she could not contain.

exchanges.speaker: filipa_de_vilhena
exchanges.text: Forty florins. Your Majesty, my family could not have given me ten. My mother said I should pray for a miracle. She said perhaps the Queen would find me a clerk or a steward, someone who did not need much dowry.

exchanges.speaker: filipa_de_vilhena
exchanges.text: With forty florins I could marry a knight, Your Majesty. A real knight. Isabel always said— She said I deserved someone who would make me laugh. She said I was too young to be so serious all the time.

exchanges.speaker: filipa_de_vilhena
exchanges.text: I'll stay. I'll stay forever if Your Majesty permits. This is my home now. Castile is my home.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz de Meneses was last. The eldest, the most composed, she listened to the offer with the stillness of someone who had learned long ago to guard her reactions.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_meneses
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I am thirty-two years old. In Portugal, I would be considered well past marriageable age. Here... Perhaps Castilian men are less particular.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_meneses
exchanges.text: I did not expect this. I expected to serve your children until they no longer needed me, and then to retire to some quiet corner of the palace or perhaps a convent. This gift tells me that Your Majesty sees us as more than servants. That you see us as women Isabel loved, and therefore worthy of love ourselves.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_meneses
exchanges.text: I accept, Your Majesty. And I will stay. Not for the dowry—though I am grateful beyond words—but because Catalina still calls for her mother in the night, and I am the closest thing to Isabel's voice she has left.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Álvaro made careful note of all four disbursements in the treasury ledger: one hundred sixty florins total, held in trust, marked for dowries. A small sum against the kingdom's vast accounts. A fortune to four women who had expected nothing.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: That was well done, Your Majesty. The court will notice. Portuguese ladies treated with honor despite their queen's death—it speaks well of Castile. And of you. It will also not go unnoticed in Lisbon. King João's health fails, but Queen Leonor and Prince Duarte will hear of this. Small kindnesses between kingdoms matter more than treaties sometimes.

encounters.recap: Juan provides forty florins dowry to each of Queen Isabel's four Portuguese ladies-in-waiting, ensuring their marriage prospects in Castile. All four accept gratefully and choose to remain, with the funds held securely in the royal treasury. The gesture demonstrates royal honor and may benefit diplomatic relations with Portugal.

roll.outcome: Exceptional Success. Lucia accepts enthusiastically and requests private meeting with Juan before formal betrothal. She brings unexpected advantages including her sharp intelligence and direct communication style.

encounters.recap: Don Íñigo López de Mendoza's delegation to Ferrara achieves exceptional success. Lucia d'Este not only accepts Juan's marriage proposal but is genuinely intrigued by his personal letter. She insists on meeting Juan privately before the formal betrothal, demonstrating her intelligence and independence. The match is agreed with favorable terms, and Lucia departs for Castile with the delegation, expected to arrive in Toledo by early November.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The bells began at dawn. Every church in Toledo joined the chorus—the great cathedral's deep bronze voice answered by the higher peals of parish churches across the city, until the air itself seemed to vibrate with sacred sound. Citizens who had traveled from as far as Burgos and Seville lined the streets from the Alcázar to the cathedral, held back by guardsmen in royal livery. Vendors sold bread and wine. Children sat on their fathers' shoulders. The autumn sun broke through morning clouds as if God Himself wished to witness the christening of Castile's heir.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The royal party departed the Alcázar at the ninth hour. First came the Guardian Company, forty knights in polished armor bearing the banners of Castile and León. Then the nobles of the realm—counts and dukes and lords who had answered the summons, their wives in silks and velvets, their households trailing behind in careful precedence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Then the godparents. Queen Leonor of Portugal, aged but unbowed, walked with the dignity of a woman who had buried children and would bury her husband soon. She wore black still—mourning for Isabel—but her mantilla was trimmed with gold, and the rosary at her belt had been blessed by three popes. Beside her walked King Alfonso V of Aragon, resplendent in crimson and gold, the arms of Aragon blazoned across his chest.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Behind them came Doña Beatriz de Meneses, carrying the infant Fernando wrapped in white silk embroidered with the lions of Castile. The child was quiet, eyes open, watching the world with the unfocused intensity of a two-month-old who did not yet know he would one day rule it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And finally, Juan. He walked alone, as was proper for a widowed king. He wore white—unusual for a monarch, but deliberate. The color of his crusaders' tabards. The color of surrender to God's will. In his arms, he carried Catalina. The princess was nineteen months old, too young to walk the full procession but too important to be left behind.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great doors stood open, revealing the vast interior lit by a thousand candles. Archbishop Alonso de Toledo waited at the baptismal font, surrounded by bishops and abbots from across the kingdom. The font itself was ancient—the same marble basin where Visigothic kings had been christened a thousand years before.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: As Juan entered, carrying Catalina, the assembly rose. He walked the length of the nave in silence, his footsteps echoing against stone. Catalina twisted in his arms to stare at the candles, the colors, the sea of unfamiliar faces. She did not cry. Isabel's daughter had inherited her mother's composure.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: In nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The ancient words rolled through the cathedral like thunder. The Archbishop spoke of baptism's meaning—the washing away of original sin, the entry into Christ's church, the beginning of a soul's journey toward salvation. He spoke of the responsibilities of godparents, of the sacred trust they accepted.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: What name is given to this child?

exchanges.speaker: leonor_of_portugal
exchanges.text: Fernando.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: And what do you ask of God's Church for Fernando?

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v_aragon
exchanges.text: Baptism.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Archbishop anointed the infant with oil—on the breast, on the shoulders, on the forehead. Fernando squirmed but did not cry. The old man's hands were gentle, practiced by decades of such ceremonies.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: Fernando, I baptize thee in the name of the Father—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Water poured over the child's head. Fernando gasped, then wailed—a lusty, healthy cry that echoed through the cathedral. Several nobles smiled. A crying child was a strong child.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: —and of the Son—

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: More water. More crying.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: —and of the Holy Spirit.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The final pouring. The Archbishop wrapped the child in a white cloth and raised him for all to see.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: Fernando, Prince of Asturias, heir to the throne of Castile and León, is received into the body of Christ. May God grant him long life, wisdom, and the strength to serve His purposes.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The cathedral erupted in response: 'Vivat! Vivat Fernando!' The bells began again—not the measured peals of summons, but the wild jubilant clamor of celebration. Outside, the crowds who had heard the cry taken up by those near the doors began cheering themselves. The sound rolled through Toledo like a wave.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: His Majesty King Juan has commanded that this joyous occasion be marked by works of charity, in memory of Queen Isabel of blessed memory, mother of Prince Fernando, who gave her life that he might live. His Majesty hereby establishes La Dote de la Reina Isabel—a perpetual charitable endowment of twenty-five thousand florins. Each year, on the third day of August—the day of Prince Fernando's birth and Queen Isabel's death—dowries shall be provided to poor Christian maidens throughout Castile and Granada who cannot otherwise marry. This charity shall continue in perpetuity, that Queen Isabel's name may be blessed by generations yet unborn.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Silence. Then, from somewhere in the nave, a woman began to weep. Others joined her. Twenty-five thousand florins—enough to provide dowries for a hundred women every year, forever. The scale of it was almost incomprehensible.

exchanges.speaker: archbishop_alonso_de_toledo
exchanges.text: Let it be recorded that this endowment is made not from the royal treasury alone, but from the King's personal fortune—that it represents not the duty of a monarch, but the love of a husband.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The ceremony concluded with prayers and blessings, and the royal party processed back to the Alcázar for the feast. The streets were even more crowded now—word of the charitable endowment had spread, and the cheering had taken on a different quality. Not just celebration of an heir, but gratitude for a king who remembered the poor on the day of his triumph.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: At the Alcázar, the great hall had been transformed. Tables stretched the length of the room, laden with food and wine. Musicians played in the gallery. The nobility of Castile ate and drank and toasted Prince Fernando's health while servants bustled between tables.

exchanges.speaker: alfonso_v_aragon
exchanges.text: A good day. Your son is christened, your charity announced, your kingdom celebrating. And in a few weeks, your new queen arrives. To Fernando. To Castile. And to the work that remains.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great hall roared with celebration around them—nobles raising cups, musicians playing, servants weaving between tables—but at the high table, a small island of quiet had formed as Juan took Catalina in his lap and shared his meal with her, one bite for him, a tiny portion for his daughter.

encounters.recap: Prince Fernando's baptism ceremony takes place in Toledo Cathedral with great pageantry. Queen Leonor of Portugal and King Alfonso V of Aragon serve as godparents. Juan establishes a perpetual charitable endowment of 25,000 florins in Isabel's memory to provide dowries for poor maidens. The celebration continues with a feast at the Alcázar, where Juan shares an intimate moment with Catalina amid the grand festivities.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great hall roared with celebration around them—nobles raising cups, musicians playing, servants weaving between tables—but at the high table, a small island of quiet had formed. Catalina sat in her father's lap, her tiny gown already stained with something that might have been gravy. She watched the chaos of the feast with wide eyes, occasionally pointing at something that caught her attention—a juggler in the corner, a lady's bright red dress, a dog that had snuck under one of the lower tables.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan cut a small piece of roasted capon and held it to her lips. She took it solemnly, chewing with the exaggerated concentration of a child who had only recently mastered the art. Then she looked up at him expectantly. He took a bite himself. Then cut another small piece for her. One for me. One for Catalina.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Queen Leonor, watching from her place of honor, smiled softly. She said nothing—what was there to say?—but her eyes glistened in the candlelight. She had seen her daughter do the same thing with this same child, in this same hall, less than a year ago.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina reached for Juan's cup. He moved it gently out of reach and offered her water instead from a smaller vessel. She accepted this substitution with the philosophical resignation of a toddler who had learned that some battles were not worth fighting.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Ball.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, mi corazón. Balls.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Want.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Perhaps tomorrow. Tonight we celebrate your brother.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She considered this, then returned her attention to the food. Juan cut another piece of meat, ate half himself, and offered her the rest. She took it from his fingers with surprising delicacy. Alfonso, who had been deep in conversation with a Valencian count, glanced over at the scene. Something flickered across his face—perhaps memory of his own failed marriage, the children he had never had with Queen María. He raised his cup slightly toward Juan, a silent acknowledgment, then returned to his conversation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The feast continued. The wine flowed. Nobles danced and laughed and made promises they might or might not keep. And at the high table, the King of Castile fed his daughter pieces of capon, one bite at a time, while her infant brother slept in his cradle nearby, unaware of the kingdom that would one day be his.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz appeared at Juan's elbow sometime later, her face gentle.

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The princess is falling asleep.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: It was true. Catalina had slumped against Juan's chest, her eyes heavy, a piece of bread still clutched in one small fist. The excitement of the day had finally overwhelmed her.

exchanges.speaker: dona_beatriz
exchanges.text: I will take her to bed, if Your Majesty permits. The nurses are waiting.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: One moment dear Beatriz. I want to introduce her to some people.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The hall quieted as Juan rose from the high table, Catalina drowsy against his shoulder. Nobles paused mid-conversation, cups halfway to lips, watching their king descend from the dais with his daughter in his arms.

encounters.recap: During Prince Fernando's baptism feast, Juan creates an intimate moment by dining with his young daughter Catalina in his lap, sharing food and tender exchanges while surrounded by the grand celebration. As the evening progresses and Catalina grows sleepy, Juan decides to introduce her to the noble guests before putting her to bed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The hall quieted as Juan rose from the high table, Catalina drowsy against his shoulder. Nobles paused mid-conversation, cups halfway to lips, watching their king descend from the dais with his daughter in his arms. This was not protocol. Kings did not circulate at feasts like common guests. They received supplicants at the high table; they did not go to them. Juan did it anyway.

exchanges.speaker: diego_hurtado_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, you honor us beyond measure.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Don Diego. Please, sit. I wanted to speak with you and your family.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Your son Don Íñigo serves me well. He writes from Ferrara that the negotiations exceeded all expectations. I am in your house's debt.

exchanges.speaker: diego_hurtado_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: Íñigo has always had a gift for words, Your Majesty. We are grateful you saw fit to trust him with such a delicate mission.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: How is your family? I see many faces here tonight—some I do not know as well as I should.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Boy.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes, mi corazón. A boy. Perhaps one day he will serve you as his grandfather serves me.

exchanges.speaker: diego_hurtado_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: House Mendoza has always served the crown, Your Majesty. We always shall.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I know. I know who stood with me when others wavered. I do not forget.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Is there anything your house needs, Don Diego? Anything I should know?

exchanges.speaker: diego_hurtado_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The northern estates suffered poor harvests this year, Your Majesty. Nothing catastrophic, but belts will be tightened. And my third son wishes to take holy orders. I had hoped he might serve in your chapel, if a position could be found.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Send him to Toledo. The Archbishop will find a place for a Mendoza.

exchanges.speaker: diego_hurtado_de_mendoza
exchanges.text: The way you carry your daughter... my Isabel used to carry our children the same way. God rest her soul.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We do what we can, Don Diego. For the ones who remain.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: These are the Mendoza's love. They are a big family like we will be when you and your brother are older.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan rose, Catalina secure in his arms, and the Mendozas bowed as he departed. The family seated beside the Mendozas wore the deep burgundy that marked their house. Don Pedro Manrique, Adelantado Mayor of León and patriarch of one of Castile's oldest noble lines, stood immediately as Juan approached.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_manrique
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. Your Highness.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Man.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_manrique
exchanges.text: I am honored by Her Highness's assessment.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for coming Don Pedro. occasions such as these remind us how important family really is. And I am glad to see that you have now met my Catalina as well. How is life in your domain?

exchanges.speaker: pedro_manrique
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is kind to ask. Life in the north continues as it always has. The harvests were adequate this year—better than Guadalajara, I am told. The frontier remains quiet, though quiet on the frontier merely means the troubles are smaller, not absent. There is some... adjustment, Your Majesty, to the new order of things. Granada's fall has changed the rhythm of the north. For generations, younger sons went south to make their names against the Moor. Now they must find other paths. Some speak of Constantinople. Others grow restless.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_castilla
exchanges.text: What my lord means to say, Your Majesty, is that the north celebrates your great victory, but also wonders what role it shall play in the kingdom you are building. We are far from Toledo. Far from Granada. Sometimes the north feels... forgotten.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Pretty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Ha! Yes Catalina, it's very pretty indeed. And it is the property of the nice man, not for Catalina to play with. Dont worry too much about too much peace. Im pretty sure we shall soon serve as christ's sword again. And the North is not forgotten, at least not by me. I wish I could visit more often, I fondly remember my journey and pilgrimage to Santiago.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_manrique
exchanges.text: The North remembers Your Majesty's pilgrimage as well. The people still speak of the young king who walked the final league barefoot, like a common penitent. The innkeepers along the Camino have dined out on the story for three years now.

exchanges.speaker: leonor_de_castilla
exchanges.text: My cousin in Astorga writes that pilgrims still ask to sleep in the same room Your Majesty occupied. The innkeeper has raised his prices accordingly.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_manrique
exchanges.text: Constantinople, Your Majesty? The rumors have reached even León. They say you have already sent knights to the Emperor. If there is to be a new crusade, the North will answer. My sons grow restless with peace, as I said. Better they spend their vigor against the Turk than in... less productive pursuits. House Manrique sent men to every campaign of the Reconquista since Covadonga. We would not wish to miss the chance to continue that tradition, even if the battlefield lies beyond the sea.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And Castille thanks you and your family for your service Pedro. But as you know, only a pope can call a crusade, not a king. We will see.

encounters.recap: Breaking protocol, Juan carries his drowsy daughter Catalina through the feast hall to personally meet with noble families. He honors House Mendoza by addressing their needs and acknowledging their loyalty, then moves to House Manrique where he discusses the northern lords' restlessness after Granada's fall and hints at future military ventures. The intimate gesture of introducing Catalina strengthens bonds with key families while demonstrating Juan's unconventional approach to kingship.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_manrique
exchanges.text: House Manrique sent men to every campaign of the Reconquista since Covadonga. We would not wish to miss the chance to continue that tradition, even if the battlefield lies beyond the sea.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Catalina, her attempt at the silver clasp thwarted, had found a new target—a loose thread on Juan's collar. She tugged at it with drowsy determination.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And Castille thanks you and your family for your service Pedro. But as you know, only a pope can call a crusade, not a king. We will see.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan inclined his head to the Manriques and moved on, Catalina now thoroughly occupied with the loose thread on his collar. The next table bore the checkered arms of the Velasco family—ancient rivals to Álvaro de Luna and historically holders of the Constableship of Castile before Álvaro had claimed it. Don Pedro Fernández de Velasco, Count of Haro, rose as Juan approached. He was a man of forty-five, proud-faced, with the careful bearing of someone who had learned to conceal his resentments behind impeccable courtesy.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. House Velasco rejoices at the christening of Prince Fernando.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The youngest Velasco daughter, a girl of perhaps six, stared openly at Catalina with the frank curiosity of one child examining another. Catalina stared back. For a moment, the two girls regarded each other across the divide of rank and family—princess and nobleman's daughter, equal only in their mutual assessment.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Girl.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you for coming and attending the ceremony. How are you doing?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Velasco daughter's eyes went wide as Catalina was set beside her. She looked to her mother again, received a small nod of permission, and then turned to the princess with the serious expression of a child entrusted with important responsibility. Catalina, freed from her father's arms, immediately reached for the girl's braided hair, which had ribbons woven through it.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Pretty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Velasco girl, emboldened, touched the embroidered lions on Catalina's stained gown.

exchanges.speaker: maria_velasco
exchanges.text: Pretty.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: Your Majesty is gracious to ask. House Velasco endures, as it always has. Our lands in the north remain productive. Our obligations to the crown are met.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: The Count was recently blessed with a grandson, Your Majesty. Our eldest son's wife delivered a healthy boy in September. We had hoped to bring him tonight, but the journey from Burgos was too arduous for an infant so young.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Really? Well congratulations! Seeing your family expand into a new generation is a blessing indeed. Your daughter seems to be getting with Catalina. What is her name?

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: Her name is María, Your Majesty. After my mother.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: She is our unexpected blessing. We thought ourselves done with children when God saw fit to give us one more.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: María is... spirited. Her nurses say she has more energy than her three brothers combined. She was furious to learn she could not train with a sword like her brothers do.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: She tried to steal one from the armory last month. The master-at-arms found her in the courtyard attempting to lift a blade twice her height.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Maria...carrying a sword? Really? I must confess I do not know if I hope Catalina will follow her example.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: I confess I did not know whether to punish her or promote her to the household guard. She told me—with great indignation—that if Castile could have a warrior king, it should also have warrior ladies. She had heard some troubadour's tale of the crusade, I think.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: She informed her brothers that she intended to conquer her own kingdom since they would inherit everything of ours. We have not yet determined which kingdom she has set her sights upon.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: She asks me every week when she will be allowed to learn to ride properly. Not side-saddle, as ladies do. Properly, like a knight. I have run out of excuses.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Are we witnessing our very own Joan of ark? And how is the mother faring, now that her daughter is so interested in playing knight?

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: Your Majesty, I have learned that God sends us the children we need, not the children we expect. When she was three, she refused to learn embroidery. She said the needle was too small to be a useful weapon. When she was four, she asked why her brothers were taught letters and she was not. When she was five...

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: When she was five, she organized the kitchen children into an army and laid siege to the henhouse. We lost six chickens before the assault was repelled.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: I have tried to teach her the womanly arts, Your Majesty. She can sew—when she chooses to. She can dance—though she prefers to lead. She has a fine singing voice, which she uses primarily to compose battle hymns. I confess I do not know what future awaits a girl such as María. She will not be content with an ordinary marriage, managing a household while her husband rides to war. But what else is there for a woman of noble birth?

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: It seems Her Highness shares some of my daughter's... determination.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Can I leave her with Maria for a moment while I meet with the other guests?

exchanges.speaker: beatriz_de_manrique
exchanges.text: Of course, Your Majesty. María will be gentle with her, I promise. For all her wildness, she is protective of those smaller than herself. She once stood guard over a nest of fallen sparrows for three days until they were strong enough to fly.

exchanges.speaker: pedro_fernandez_de_velasco
exchanges.text: We are honored, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: maria_velasco
exchanges.text: I will protect her. No one will hurt her while I am here.

encounters.recap: Juan continues his rounds among the nobility with Catalina, moving from House Manrique to House Velasco. The interaction transforms when Catalina bonds with six-year-old María Velasco, a spirited girl with martial ambitions. The informal play between the children breaks down the formal barriers, warming the previously guarded Count of Haro toward Juan. Juan entrusts Catalina to the Velasco family's care while he continues greeting other nobles.

roll.outcome: Transformative — Stories for Generations. The night becomes legendary. For years afterward, nobles will tell their children about when King Juan walked among them with Princess Catalina. The gesture transcends politics and becomes part of Juan's personal mythology. Houses that had grievances find them harder to maintain against a king who held their children's hands.

encounters.recap: A roll to determine how the Castilian nobility reacts to Juan's unprecedented behavior at the baptism feast—leaving the high table to circulate among guests with Catalina, sitting with families as near-equals, and trusting the Velascos with his daughter. The result shows the night becomes legendary, transforming Juan's reputation and beginning to heal old wounds, particularly with the Velasco house.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The days following the baptism settled into a rhythm Juan had rarely known as king—domestic, quiet, almost ordinary. He took breakfast with Catalina each morning in the small solar adjoining his chambers, away from the formality of the great hall. She had developed firm opinions about food: bread was acceptable, eggs were suspicious, honey was essential. Juan learned to negotiate with a nineteen-month-old over the consumption of vegetables, a campaign that proved more challenging than several battles he had fought.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Catalina. One bite of carrot.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: For Papa?

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: No.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: For... the horse? The horse wants you to eat the carrot.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A long, suspicious stare. Then, grudgingly, one bite. Victory. Fernando was easier, in the way of infants—his needs were simple and immediate. Hungry. Tired. Wet. Content. Juan spent hours in the nursery, watching his son sleep, marveling at the smallness of his fingers. Sometimes he held the boy against his chest and simply breathed, feeling the tiny heartbeat against his own.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: He has Isabel's nose. She always hated her nose. Said it was too strong for her face. But on him...

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It suits him.

exchanges.speaker: beatriz
exchanges.text: It suited her too. She just couldn't see it.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The early November leaves had fallen from Toledo's trees and the first cold winds swept down from the Guadarramas when word came that the delegation from Ferrara had crossed the Pyrenees. Don Íñigo's courier reported their progress: Lucia d'Este traveled in a covered litter, accompanied by her Italian household, moving at the measured pace appropriate for a future queen.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: Within the week. Shall I begin preparations for her reception, Your Majesty? The appropriate ceremonies, the—

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. But... She asked to meet me privately first. Before any formal announcement. See that it happens.

exchanges.speaker: alvaro_de_luna
exchanges.text: And if she... if the meeting does not go well?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Then we will discover that together. She is coming to see if my eyes match my letter, she said. I intend to show her that they do.

encounters.recap: Over ten days following the baptism feast, Juan settles into a domestic routine with his children—morning breakfasts with Catalina involving negotiations over food, quiet hours holding Fernando in the nursery. The Portuguese ladies find their footing in court, and Juan manages matters of state between family time. When word arrives that Lucia d'Este approaches Toledo, Juan makes careful preparations including commissioning an elegant sapphire ring and arranging for their first private meeting, choosing to present himself and his children to her rather than meeting alone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The choice would be hers. Juan stood at the window of his chambers as the sun sank toward the western hills. Somewhere beyond the walls, a woman he had never met was approaching—a woman who had read his letter and declared she would see for herself whether his eyes matched his words. The ring sat in its box on the table beside him. The solar was prepared. The wines were ready. All that remained was the meeting itself.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I go to the prepared dinner and wait for Lucia there and take Catalina, Fernando and two Doña's with me. I want her to meet me and my children as well.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The solar glowed warmly in the candlelight as Juan settled into his chair. A fire crackled in the hearth, casting dancing shadows across the walls. Through the arched windows, the last light of autumn faded over the garden courtyard below. Catalina sat on a cushion near the fire, engaged in serious conversation with her wooden horse. She had been bathed and dressed in a clean gown of pale blue—a minor miracle of negotiation with the nurses—though her hair was already escaping its ribbons. Fernando slept in a cradle nearby, wrapped in white linen, his tiny chest rising and falling with the steady rhythm of infant dreams. Doña Beatriz sat a respectful distance away, close enough to assist with the children if needed, far enough to allow privacy. Doña Leonor de Almeida had taken the other position, her eyes bright with curiosity about the woman who would become her new queen. The table was set for two, as planned. The wines stood ready—the Ribera del Duero already breathing, the white from Rueda chilled in a basin of cold water, the Málaga and the monastery vintage waiting in reserve. Ferrarese cheeses and Castilian delicacies occupied silver platters. Everything was elegant without being ostentatious. The ring box rested in Juan's doublet, a small weight against his chest.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Papa. Hungry.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Doña Beatriz moved to offer the princess a small piece of bread, which Catalina accepted with the gravity of a diplomat receiving tribute. Minutes passed. The fire crackled. Fernando stirred in his sleep, made a small sound, then settled again. Then—footsteps in the corridor. A soft knock at the door.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Your Majesty. The Lady Lucia d'Este.

encounters.recap: Juan prepares for his first meeting with Lucia d'Este by setting up a private dinner in the solar with his children Catalina and Fernando present, along with their attendants. As evening falls, Lucia arrives at the prepared chamber where Juan waits with the engagement ring and an elegant but modest supper arrangement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The woman who entered the solar was not what the poets would have described. She was better. Lucia d'Este was tall for a woman—nearly Juan's own height—with a carriage that spoke of years learning to move through Italian courts without apology. Her hair was dark, almost black, worn in the Ferrarese fashion: partially braided and pinned, partially falling in waves past her shoulders. It framed a face that was striking rather than merely pretty—high cheekbones, a strong nose, a mouth that seemed poised perpetually on the edge of either a smile or a cutting remark. But it was her eyes that commanded attention. They were grey-green, the color of the sea before a storm, and they swept the room with an intelligence that missed nothing.

exchanges.speaker: catalina
exchanges.text: Pretty.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Lucia, how wonderful to meet you. I am Juan and I would like you to meet my little Catalina and baby Fernando as well.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Thank you, small one. I see. A fine horse. Does he have a name? An honest name. I approve.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: You bring your children to our first meeting. In Ferrara, such things would be handled by nurses until the marriage was secure. The children presented formally, once agreements were signed.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: You have gone to considerable trouble, Your Majesty. The wines. The food from home. This room. I am trying to determine whether this is thoughtfulness or strategy. In my experience, the two often wear the same face.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: It just felt right to meet you with my children as well. You were going to meet them anyway and I did not want to occupy your mind with questions about who and how they are. But you have now seen them and I have asked to be alone for now. Come, have a seat, you must be tired after such a long journey.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: Yes. I am tired. Five weeks on the road, through mountain passes and autumn rains, sleeping in monastery guest houses and provincial inns. There was one inn near Toulouse where the bed had more inhabitants than I did. I shall be writing a strongly worded letter to someone, though I have not yet determined whom.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_d_este
exchanges.text: I was told Castilian wine is inferior to Italian. I was also told you are mad, that you speak to God directly, that you conquered Granada through divine intervention rather than military competence, and that your first wife died of a broken heart because you loved war more than her. I have learned to be skeptical of what I am told. Sit with me, Your Majesty. Pour me some of this allegedly inferior wine. And tell me which of the rumors are true.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What sort of wine do you like my lady? A strong red? A supple white? Or a sweet one?

roll.outcome: Cautious Interest. The approach lands acceptably. Lucia appreciates the informality but maintains her reserve—she did not travel across Europe to fall into anyone's arms on the first evening. She warms slightly to Catalina (children are hard to resist), asks appropriate questions about Fernando, but keeps Juan at a careful distance. A foundation, not a connection.

encounters.recap: Juan meets Lucia d'Este for the first time in his solar, introducing her immediately to his children Catalina and Fernando. The roll determines Lucia's reaction to this approach - she shows cautious interest, appreciating his informality while maintaining careful reserve. She engages politely with the children but keeps Juan at a distance, testing whether his actions match the promises in his letter. The meeting begins with mutual assessment rather than immediate connection.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: I was told Castilian wine is inferior to Italian. I was also told you are mad, that you speak to God directly, that you conquered Granada through divine intervention rather than military competence, and that your first wife died of a broken heart because you loved war more than her. I have learned to be skeptical of what I am told. Sit with me, Your Majesty. Pour me some of this allegedly inferior wine. And tell me which of the rumors are true.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What sort of wine do you like my lady? A strong red? A supple white? Or a sweet one?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: That depends entirely on what I am drinking it for. A strong red when I wish to feel bold. A white when I wish to think clearly. A sweet wine when I wish to remember that the world contains pleasures as well as duties. Tonight I am meeting a man who may become my husband. A man I know only through a letter and the reports of others—reports which, as I mentioned, have been contradictory at best. I think I wish to think clearly. But I also wish to feel bold enough to ask the questions I came here to ask. Perhaps you should choose for me, Your Majesty. It will tell me something about you—whether you wish me clear-headed or pliable, whether you pay attention to what I actually said or simply hear what you expect to hear.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well, let me start from the beginning then. I have been king since I was a child. I always knew those around me were taking advantage of me, but what could I do? I was often a captive in my own palace. One day I decided that it must end. And I realized that I had to do something extraordinary and unexpected for me to take control of my kingdom. To truly be king. So I went on a pilgrimage. Insane, since the realm was on the verge of rebellion. If I left but for a short while, the sharks would close in. But I had to try, so I gambled it all. I guess that is where the rumours started about me talking with God and all other nonsense. I indicated that I would leave on pilgrimage and would let the divine spirit guide me on my journey. I knew from the start that I had to go to Rome and ask for crusade. Only that would give me the authority to unite the realm not only under my rule, but it would also unite the kingdom against our common enemy. I had to rely on my divine guidance quite often for I went back to my palace to retrieve my father's sword, right at the moment when a rebellious plot was revealed. Maybe the divine inspired me to have someone signal to me when the rebels entered the meeting room or maybe the divine inspired me to actually want them to reveal themselves the moment they thought me gone. Or maybe both. Anyway, the result was that the rebels died an unfortunate death and my realm is now secure. And everyone thinks I am still the mad king who leaves to go on a pilgrimage while his nobles plot his downfall. But there is another side as well. I really do take my faith very seriously and I want to make sure I never become an arrogant, heartless king I see some others become. I do ride out at the head of my knights in my white armour, knowing full well that I am a major target for every enemy lance and archer. I have learned to not be afraid and I gladly lay my life in God's hands. Now dont confuse this bravery with recklessness. I try not to be. But I know that if I can approach a fort alone and negotiate a surrender, purely by my own presence, I know I will save my men and that it's a risk worth taking. More wine?

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: I have not yet tested this one, Your Majesty. You speak faster than I drink. So. The madness is a mask. The divine inspiration is... partly genuine faith, partly political theater. You let your enemies believe you a fool guided by heaven, while you arrange their deaths with precision. And you ride at the head of your knights not because you seek martyrdom, but because you have calculated that your presence saves more lives than your caution would. In Ferrara, my uncle is considered a master of such games. He has survived assassination attempts, rival claimants, and the endless scheming of Milan and Venice by letting everyone underestimate him. He plays the simple soldier, the bluff condottiero, while his mind works three moves ahead. I recognize the pattern. I am... familiar with the difference between what a ruler shows and what a ruler is. But there is something I do not yet understand. You speak of faith genuinely. You speak of not wishing to become heartless. You established a charity of twenty-five thousand florins in your dead wife's name—not from the treasury, but from your personal fortune. You carried your daughter through a feast, introducing her to every noble house like she was a treasure rather than a political asset. The mask I understand. The calculation I understand. But underneath it... is there actually a man who believes what he pretends to believe? Who loves what he appears to love? Or is that simply another layer of the performance?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: That is what is so difficult to explain. Every time I speak about this, I risk people thinking me mad, delusional or... having messianic thoughts. We live in this world Lucia. A world full of hunger, of pain, of injustice. But there is another world A world that is just, good and right. And every time we act not out of pride but out of generosity, when we act out of forgiveness and love instead of hate, we move our world just a little bit closer to God's kingdom on earth. I know we will never reach it Lucia. We never will, no matter how hard we try, there will always be enough greed and pride in the hearts of men to tear down every tower of goodwill. But we must try, for if we stop trying all is lost. It is in this struggle that we find out who we truly are, who we can be. How we can serve each other and God as well. And sometimes...when there is a special moment that belongs in His kingdom, I can see it. A true good deed. The prsence of God's kingdom in this world. It is beautiful Lucia. It is something no priest can bestow or take away. God exists between two people doing good things. It is what I truly fight for and believe in. What guides my every action. How can I bring this world closer to God's kingdom. Ha! Or to put it more simply and without complicated rethoric; how can I make this world better.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The fire crackled in the silence that followed. Lucia did not move, did not speak. Her wine glass remained suspended halfway to her lips, forgotten. Juan had seen many reactions to his words over the years—confusion, suspicion, the careful blankness of courtiers who thought their king mad but dared not say so. He had seen Fray Hernando's troubled concern, Álvaro's pragmatic tolerance, the whispered worries of nobles who wondered if their monarch heard voices. Lucia's reaction was none of these. Her eyes glistened in the candlelight. Not tears—not quite—but something had shifted behind them. The sharp assessment, the political calculation, the careful distance she had maintained since entering the room... all of it had cracked, just slightly. She set down her wine glass with exaggerated care, as if she needed a moment to collect herself.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: My mother died when I was seven. Fever. I remember very little of her, but I remember one thing she told me. She said: 'Lucia, the world is full of men who want things. Power, gold, women, land. Be wary of all of them. But if you ever meet a man who wants to make things better—truly better, not just better for himself—hold onto him. They are rarer than diamonds.' I have been in courts my entire life. I have watched my uncle navigate between predators. I have seen cardinals speak of God while counting their gold. I have heard princes quote scripture to justify atrocities. I came here expecting to find another performer. A clever king with a good reputation and a talent for spectacle. I did not expect... this. You actually believe it. Not as doctrine, not as politics. You see something. Something real. My confessor in Ferrara would call what you describe heresy, you know. The presence of God between people, without the intercession of the Church? Dangerous talk. I think I like dangerous talk. You asked me which rumors were true. Now I ask you: the charity for the dowries, in your wife's name. The way you carried your daughter tonight. The way you speak of God's kingdom. Was Isabel part of this? Did she see what you see?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Where two or three of my number are gathered and my words are spoken, I am among you. Hardly heresy I believe. Maybe those who deny God's presence are themselves the heretics. I am trying to help reform the church, did you know? There is only so much I can do and a few weeks at Basel almost drove me insane, but we try. Isabel...she was always very pious. In a very committed way. She was very young when we married, maybe some more years would have granted her more wisdom. But she had a faith so pure and convincing, we shared this vision yes. But it mostly involved the joy of our family. Becoming a father has been the most pure vision of God's kingdom I ever saw. I see it still when I look at Catalina and how she is curious and discovers the world. The painting I had made of our wedding was meant to convey exactly that. The attainment of the kingdom of heaven through her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You loved her. Not merely as a king loves a queen who does her duty. You loved her. I have been told many things about what to expect from royal marriage. Duty. Alliance. Children. Tolerance of mistresses. A shared table and separate beds. No one told me to expect a man who speaks of his dead wife with such tenderness. Who sees the kingdom of heaven in his daughter's curiosity. I am not Isabel, Your Majesty. I am not young, not pure, not... uncomplicated in my faith. I have read things my confessor would burn me for. I have asked questions that made my tutors stammer. I have a tongue that has gotten me into trouble more times than I can count. My uncle once said I would either marry a king or be locked in a convent, because no ordinary man would tolerate me. I came here to see if your eyes matched your letter. They do. More than I expected. But I need to know something else. Something the letter did not address. If I marry you—if I become Queen of Castile, stepmother to your children, partner in this vision you speak of—what place will I hold? Will I be a companion in this work you describe? Will I have a voice, a role, a purpose beyond bearing heirs? Or will I be kept safe and comfortable while you ride off to Constantinople and Granada and wherever else God's kingdom calls you, waiting at home like a portrait on a wall?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: My apologies my lady. We have dwelled on the dead for long enough now. I know you are not Isabel, nor do I require or expect it. I would like to get to know you better. Would you like to have a walk with me in the garden?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia looked at his offered hand for a moment. Then, unexpectedly, she laughed—a real laugh, warm and surprised.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You are remarkable, Your Majesty. I ask you a direct question about my future role as your queen, and you invite me to walk in a garden. In Ferrara, that would be considered an evasion. A deflection. But you are not evading, are you? You are telling me that such questions cannot be answered in a single evening. That you wish to know me before you promise me things you may not be able to give. That is either very wise or very infuriating. I have not yet decided which. I have been in carriages and litters and monastery guest rooms for five weeks. I have not walked anywhere simply for the pleasure of walking since I left Ferrara. Show me your garden, Your Majesty. And perhaps while we walk, you might tell me what you actually want from a wife. Not what duty requires. Not what diplomacy demands. What you want.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She placed her hand in his. Her fingers were cool from holding the wine glass, her grip firm and unhesitating. Up close, she smelled faintly of rosewater and travel dust—the latter a reminder that she had come to him straight from the road, without the hours of preparation most noble ladies would have demanded.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think God has given men and women different gifts and therefore different roles to play in the world. A king and a queen have different roles as well. Being queen of Castille can be quite exhausting, I must warn you. But now that I have gotten to know you a little bit, I think you will do just fine. Dont worry too much about what is expected of you as queen. Just do what feels right. It's what I do. You know, me and my advisors discussed many potential brides, and the fact you have a sharp tongue is well known. That and your sharp mind was what really made it easy to think you would be a great queen. And also...Lucia, you must know that men cannot talk about you without mentioning your beauty as well. Not only are you as sharp and quick as I had been told, you are simply the most beautiful woman I have ever met. And that is the honest truth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The playful push caught her off guard—her eyes widened for a split second before she caught her balance, a surprised laugh escaping her.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Did you just— The King of Castile just pushed me. In a garden. Like a boy teasing a girl at a village fair. My uncle told me it would be my downfall. That no man of consequence wants a wife who speaks her mind. I informed him that any man who could not tolerate my mind did not deserve the rest of me. He called me impossible. I thanked him for the compliment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But when Juan spoke of her beauty—called her the most beautiful woman he had ever met—she stopped walking. For a long moment, she said nothing. The moonlight caught her face, those grey-green eyes unreadable.

roll.outcome: Strong emotional connection established. Lucia is deeply moved by Juan's sincerity and vision. Mutual attraction confirmed.

encounters.recap: Juan and Lucia's first private meeting reveals deep compatibility as he explains his faith-driven kingship and she responds with unexpected emotional openness. Their conversation moves from political assessment to genuine connection, culminating in a moonlit garden walk where attraction and understanding flourish.
