exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Did you just— The King of Castile just pushed me. In a garden. Like a boy teasing a girl at a village fair.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But she was smiling, and something in her posture had shifted. The last remnants of courtly formality were crumbling. They walked in silence for a moment, their footsteps soft on the stone path. The moonlight cast long shadows through the bare branches overhead. Somewhere, water trickled in a fountain.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: My uncle told me it would be my downfall. That no man of consequence wants a wife who speaks her mind. I informed him that any man who could not tolerate my mind did not deserve the rest of me. He called me impossible. I thanked him for the compliment.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But when Juan spoke of her beauty—called her the most beautiful woman he had ever met—she stopped walking. For a long moment, she said nothing. The moonlight caught her face, those grey-green eyes unreadable.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Men have spoken of my beauty my entire life. They speak of it as if it belongs to them—as if my face is a painting hung for their pleasure, my body a territory to be claimed. They speak of it before they speak of anything else. Often, it is all they speak of. You spoke of my mind first. My tongue. You mentioned beauty last, almost as an afterthought. Do you know how rare that is? How many men have courted me who could not tell you a single thing I had ever said, but could describe my eyes in fourteen different poems?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She stepped closer. Close enough that he could see the faint freckles across her nose that the candlelight inside had hidden.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Isabel was fortunate. To have been seen by you. Truly seen. I think... I think I would like to be seen like that too.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I did not want to lie to you and be honest from the start. Being queen will not be easy. I am very demanding of myself and those around me. That usually involves me moving around a lot. Next spring I will leave for Rome and then Constantinople for example. And this will be a good example of what being queen will mean. I have a flagship, specially designed to accommodate a queen and her handmaidens. If you should want it, you can come with me. See the eternal city. Or if you prefer to stay in Toledo, you can choose to do so as well. You will have full freedom to be regent-queen in my absence should you desire it. You dont have to decide now, by the way. What I mean to say is...I hope for us to be a team.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You would take me to Constantinople? You would let me stand beside you as you meet the Emperor of the Romans? See the Hagia Sophia? In Ferrara, my aunt—my uncle's wife—has not left the city walls in eleven years. She manages the household. She bears children. She waits. When I asked her once if she wished to travel with my uncle on his campaigns, she looked at me as if I had suggested she sprout wings and fly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: She turned her hand in his, so that their fingers intertwined. It was a deliberate gesture—a choice.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: A team. Not a king and his ornament. Not a husband and his broodmare. You mean this. You actually mean this. I have spent my whole life preparing for a cage. A gilded cage, yes. Comfortable. Safe. But a cage nonetheless. Every lesson, every expectation, every warning from my uncle and my tutors—all of it preparing me to be kept. To smile and nod and produce heirs and never, ever want more. And now you stand here in a moonlit garden and offer me... partnership. Purpose. A ship designed for a queen. Either you are the most extraordinary man I have ever met, or this is an elaborate trap I am too tired to perceive. Tell me it is not a trap, Juan. Tell me you mean what you say.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: O but it is a trap Lucia! And I am about to spring it. After hearing about you from others and now after meeting you in person, I know that you are every bit the sharp and competent queen I would hope for. But you must choose me as well. What I ask of you is not easy. Not only will you work together with me to make Castille better, you will also become step-mother to Catalina and Fernando. Others will look to your every move and I will be called to war often. I promise to not only be a good husband but to treat you as partner. I will always value your council and will always trust you. I will protect you, shield you and keep you safe. Would you despite everything be my wife Lucia?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia stood frozen for a long moment, looking down at the kneeling king, the open box, the ring that caught the moonlight like a captured star. Then she laughed. Not a polite laugh, not a courtly titter—a real laugh, the kind that escaped before one could catch it. Her hand flew to her mouth, and when she lowered it, her eyes were bright with tears she did not bother to hide.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You impossible man. You impossible man. I crossed half of Europe expecting to find a political arrangement. A tolerable husband at best. A gilded cage. And instead I find a man who kneels in a garden and asks me to choose him. Who speaks of God's kingdom as if it were something real. Who pushed me like a village boy and showed me a ring designed for me, not for 'a queen'. Yes. Yes, I will be your wife. Yes, I will be stepmother to Catalina and Fernando. Yes, I will stand beside you in Rome and Constantinople and wherever else God calls you. Yes, I will be your partner, your counsel, your queen. But I warn you, Juan of Castile, I will not be a quiet wife. I will argue with you. I will tell you when you are wrong. I will drive your advisors to distraction and scandalize your court with my opinions. If you wanted meek and biddable, you have made a terrible mistake. But if you wanted a partner—a true partner—then you have found one. And I will fight beside you for this vision you speak of. This kingdom of heaven you see glimpses of. I want to see it too. Show me. Show me everything.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia let out a startled yelp as Juan swept her off her feet—a sound utterly undignified for a future queen, which only made her laugh harder. She did not struggle. Her arms wrapped around his neck instinctively, her face close to his as he carried her through the moonlit garden and back into the warmth of the solar. When he set her down in her chair, she was still laughing, wiping tears from her cheeks with the back of her hand—the hand that now bore his ring.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: You are mad. The King of Castile, carrying his betrothed through the garden like a sack of Ferrarese grain. I will tell our children about this, you know. When they ask how their father proposed. I will tell them he knelt in the moonlight and then picked me up before I could say anything else. They will think us both mad. It will be wonderful. Sit. Eat. We have barely touched this feast you prepared. And I believe you promised to prove that Castilian wine is not inferior to Italian. The white is... acceptable. But I reserve judgment on the reds.

roll.outcome: Transcendent Moment. Something shifts in the moonlit garden. Lucia's acceptance becomes more than a yes—it becomes a vow. She speaks of what she sees in him, what she hopes to build together. The ring slides onto her finger like it was always meant to be there. This is the beginning of a true partnership, perhaps even love.

encounters.recap: Juan's marriage proposal to Lucia d'Este reaches its climax in the moonlit garden. After an evening of deep conversation, Juan kneels before her with the specially designed ring, honestly describing the challenges of being queen while promising true partnership. A roll of 83 produces a transcendent moment—Lucia accepts with overwhelming emotion, declaring her willingness to be his partner in all things while warning she will never be a quiet wife. The evening ends with Juan carrying her back to their table, both laughing and crying, the ring fitting perfectly on her finger.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan filled two glasses with the robust Ribera del Duero—the wine Álvaro had sworn could silence Italian skepticism—and settled into the chair across from Lucia. The fire crackled between them, casting warm light across the remnants of their feast. He told her everything. He told her of the Emperor's letter—how Constantinople had shrunk from a million souls to barely forty thousand, how entire districts lay empty with fields growing inside the ancient walls. How the Theodosian Walls that had stood for a thousand years now crumbled, requiring more gold than the Empire possessed to repair. How the city that had preserved Roman civilization while the West fell into darkness now paid tribute to the Ottoman Sultan like a vassal, bleeding three hundred thousand silver coins each year simply to survive. He told her of Sotomayor's three hundred knights, already arrived, already working to shore up defenses. Of the remaining seven hundred he planned to bring in spring. Of the sixty thousand florins already sent for wall repairs—and how even that enormous sum was insufficient. He told her of the Emperor's request: not just soldiers, not just gold, but Juan himself. A personal visit. A statement to the world that Christendom had not abandoned the Queen of Cities. He told her of his promise to Pope Eugenius—made at Rome, sealed at the Council of Basel—that Castile would stand for the defense of the Faith. That the Reconquista's completion was not an ending but a beginning. And he told her the darker truth beneath it all: that Constantinople would likely fall regardless. That the Ottoman tide might be too great to stop. That he was committing treasure and knights and perhaps his own life to a cause that history might judge as hopeless.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: But if we do nothing, if we let the city fall without raising a hand... then we are not the Christendom we claim to be. And whatever comes after, we will deserve it. That is where I am going in spring. That is what is at stake.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia had listened without interruption, her wine untouched, her grey-green eyes fixed on his face throughout. The playfulness of moments before had vanished, replaced by something more serious—the sharp mind he had been promised, fully engaged. When he finished, she was quiet for a long moment.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Forty thousand people. In a city built for a million. I have read of Constantinople in books. The libraries. The Hagia Sophia. The scholars who kept alive what Rome forgot. To think of it dying slowly, district by district, like a body losing feeling in its limbs... You said earlier that I could come with you. To Rome and Constantinople. Did you mean it? Truly? You would take your new queen into... that?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Yes. Yes, exactly. We will be travelling with heavy escort, like I said brave but never suicidal. We have to listen to what the emperor has to say. If he is too proud to listen, If he rather die on his walls, I cannot stop him. My mind is already racing Lucia. I have not talked about this with anybody, but I will with you. I will demand heavy dependency of the Greeks on me before I will even consider help. Facing the ottomans for the coming 50 years is a colossal commitment and I will not do it as just a helper. Bleeding my own men dry for someone else's kingdom. That would be unjust to my men. I will demand they recognize my authority.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia's eyes widened slightly. She set down her wine glass with deliberate care.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Your authority. You mean... more than an alliance. More than military coordination. The Emperor of the Romans—the inheritor of Constantine, of Justinian, of a thousand years of unbroken succession—recognizing the authority of the King of Castile. Juan, that is... that is extraordinary. The Byzantine court is the proudest in Christendom. They still call Western kings 'barbarians' in their private councils. They consider the Pope a schismatic upstart. But they are also desperate. You said it yourself: forty thousand people, tribute to the Sultan, walls crumbling. A drowning man does not argue about the hand that reaches for him. What form would this authority take? Vassalage? A personal oath to you? Integration into— You conquered Granada. You completed the Reconquista. You are building a fleet, reforming the Church, sending knights across the Mediterranean. Juan. What exactly are you building? What is the shape of the thing you see when you close your eyes and imagine victory?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan stood up and moved very close to her. He whispered in her ear his deepest ambition: to take the imperial crown of Constantinople and be emperor of Portugal, Castile, Navarre, Aragon, Naples, Sicily and Greece. Lucia went utterly still. Juan could feel her breath catch, her body frozen mere inches from his. For a long moment, she did not move, did not speak—did not even seem to breathe. Then, very slowly, she pulled back just enough to look at his face. Her grey-green eyes searched his, wide with something that was not quite fear, not quite awe, but some strange admixture of both.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: Dios mío. You are not mad. You are terrifying. There is a difference. I see that now. Portugal through marriage—your mother's claim, or a future union. Navarre is contested, but achievable. Aragon through Alfonso, if he dies without heir—he has none, and you are close. Naples falls to Alfonso first, then to you by the same succession. Sicily follows Naples. And Constantinople... Constantinople you buy. With knights. With gold. With the only hand reaching for a drowning man. You make John VIII swear to you, and when the city survives because of Castilian steel, the people will remember who saved them. And when the Emperor dies... An empire. Not Holy Roman—that is German, and tied to electors who would never choose a Spaniard. But Roman. The true Rome. Constantinople and the West, united under one crown for the first time since... since Theodosius. Over a thousand years. And you whisper this to me. On the night of our betrothal. In a moonlit garden. What manner of husband have I chosen?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Your mind works quickly. That is indeed more or less how I plan to do it. But please, we are too far away from it to even mention the possibility except between just us two. Please, be careful with what you say to whom.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lucia nodded slowly, composing herself with visible effort. The trembling stilled. The sharp-tongued diplomat reassembled herself from the woman who had, for a moment, been shaken to her core.

exchanges.speaker: lucia_deste
exchanges.text: I grew up in Ferrara. Where my uncle survives by knowing which words to speak aloud, which to whisper, and which to never say at all. Where a careless phrase at dinner can mean a dagger in the dark by morning. I know how to keep secrets, Juan. I have kept them since I was old enough to understand what they cost. This one I will carry to my grave if necessary. It will not pass my lips—not to confessor, not to family, not to any living soul. But know this: you have given me something tonight far more dangerous than a sapphire. You have given me the shape of your ambition. You have trusted me with the thing that could destroy you if spoken to the wrong ears. I will not forget that trust. And I will not betray it. Now. We should eat something, or the servants will wonder what we have been doing all this time. And I believe you still owe me proof that Castilian reds can stand against Italian.

encounters.recap: Juan reveals his deepest imperial ambitions to Lucia, sharing his plans to demand authority over Constantinople in exchange for military aid, ultimately seeking to unite Portugal, Castile, Navarre, Aragon, Naples, Sicily, and Greece under one crown. Lucia comprehends the vast scope of his vision and solemnly promises to keep this dangerous secret, understanding the trust he has placed in her.
